segments.text: The interesting thing is, and I have to remind you of, while HUD missed the opportunity to become a central timing agency for whatever reason, the old Bureau of Public Roads and its successor, the U.S. Department of Transportation, particularly the Highway Administration, the Mass Transportation Administration, stepped in.

very boldly, and had it not been for the old Bureau of Public Works and its insistence on what you and I call comprehensive planning as part of the Transition Study, planning would have vanished altogether.
It didn't come from out.
They didn't know what to do with it or what to do.
It was really the engineers who said, you've got to have a plan
It was people like Siegel saying, how can you go out there and confront the public if you don't have anything to show for that you thought about it and that this is a rational thing?
You've got to do that.
You can't just go spend money.
And it was that simple, common sense, political instinct that saved planning, and then we had the planning requirements and the early transportation acts, and it happened to this day.
And interestingly enough,
Nixon didn't go out of his way to do positive things in urban areas.
He nevertheless is really responsible for the regional councils.
They had this feeble attempt of local coordination, and it wouldn't work.
And it was under the Nixon administration that the presidential edict was declared from now on.
Every project that is federally financed has to be okayed by some regional entity, council, governments, whatever, that represents elected officials.
This is not good, but it is better than nothing.
You're talking about A-95?
Yeah, when it got started.
It came out of the Nixon administration.
Well, it actually started in Kennedy's.
But it didn't have any...
There was a secret memo, actually, that came...
from Office of Management and Budget, but it never got outside of the Bureau.
But it was searching for something like that.
And then it eventually, it had to happen.
There were too many federal programs that were going in different directions.
And what was wrong with all of that stuff initially was that the people who served on these regional entities, planning entities, whatever they were, had no
power to commit their own constituent governance.
And Nixon changed that by a simple directive that, I forget the number of that, but he said that the governing boards of regional councils had to be composed of elected officials.
And they had to be in proportion to the entities that they represented.
And while this did not happen,

legal force beyond that it nevertheless had a very practical political impact in that it brought the legislative bodies of the municipalities and governing bodies of counties in a given region into the accountability process well you voted for it and the man serving on the regional council wasn't just there as citizen shorts he was there as
Councilman Schultz, who represented the Council of Central City.
Victor Jones had a large part to play in recommending that to the feds from the Institute of Governmental Affairs in Berkeley.
So I think there will be a strengthening of these kinds of agencies anyway, and I think with all this continued demand for people.
Now, another interesting thing with the Tax Reform Act,
The time period when real estate development was financed largely by people who had a need for tax shelter was over.
Consequently, the individual investor is placed in a weak position vis-a-vis the institutional investor, particularly the pension funds and the insurance companies, who will now pretty much control
the flow of capital into real estate development.
And one of the consequences of this, I believe, and others have said the same thing, that will be a substantial professionalizing of real estate activities.
There will be no more of this good old boy routine with young men operating in the seat of his pens, but a serious developer who will have a competent staff, that competent staff will
deal effectively with the staff of the pension fund that is equally competent.
And they will very critically examine propositions, approvals, participation, so that the quality of development should be higher in the next 30, 40 years than it has been.
And from our point of view, the point of view of academic institutions, a greater responsibility to produce more adequately trained individuals
at the master's level and the doctoral level who can perform these functions.
Yeah, it seems too that academia can pick up another void, and that would be to assist in monitoring the market and to make reliable data available to developers on the current status of the market.
Yeah, centers such as ours and the Real Estate Research Center and others are doing that.
And a third of our work in the Center for Urban Affairs is exactly that.
We did recently this summer here in San Antonio, trying to identify and establish a reliable database for all available residential lots that are now on the market.
Things of that sort are very important.

I think you hit on something that's critical for our existence and for the development community and the real estate community, that we will finally agree that the database that we all use should be uniform and above board.
an objective database and everybody uses it and so consequently decisions based on that should be much more objective.

It's interesting in the greater Houston area now the Houston-Galveston Area Council is providing that function and all the municipalities including Houston have agreed that they will use the database and the forecasts that are generated by HGAC.
so that they don't end up with two forecasts like the state of Texas has.
So to sum up the question, I think the future has never been better for planning entities in the academic environment.
We combine planning with research and practice, and you can't ask for more.
How do you feel to go on to a somewhat different
variation of this topic, how do you feel about the fact that we have three planning degree granting programs in Texas?
Well, traditionally the University of Texas has followed different policies and
educational philosophies.
For whatever reason, Texas A&M has been recognized as the planning program that is primarily physical planning, also deals with social aspects, but it deals with it in the sense of developing
potential management personnel that have the skills of dealing with all these issues immediately.
University of Texas is a more, I think, broad general education type institution that is not overly concerned with applicability of skills.
The person goes through that, maybe educated person in some way, but is not a skillful person.
In our programs, you only want to produce a school for the persons who are also educated.
That's the University of Texas in Austin.
I was really quite surprised to learn that they offer no course in the history of planning in Texas.
They don't even think of themselves, and that's a very interesting observation, because they really don't think of themselves as
founding professionals as we do.
For instance, as far as I know, there's only one member of the faculty who even holds membership in the American Institute of Certified Planners.
And that's rather strange.
University of Texas in Arlington has never been able to overcome its image as a community college, in a sense.
They have all kinds of advanced degrees, but it is essentially dead.
And also, they've been
periodically troubled severely by total reorganization within the university structure, which essentially sets them back substantially every time it happens.
So, I haven't paid a lot of attention to UTI, but I have no really education to deal with that, because it just seemed to be, in other words, a threat to us
And UT Austin has never been a threat to us either.
As a matter of fact, we rather enjoy a cordial, collegiate relationship with the University of Texas in Austin and send each other students.
It's not unusual for someone to come here and say, Professor so-and-so at Austin suggested that I should perhaps talk to you because your program seems to be more to my liking.
And we've done the same.
It's just a different orientation.
UT Arlington, I think, enjoys a superb location for a department of planning.
They should be able to do better than Austin and Power Station.
They should be on top of the world.
But they don't.
And interestingly enough, University of Houston had never even attempted to deal with planning.
It's hostile to it.
Rice has a few courses that they call planning, and they're pretty good, but no degree.
Texas Southern has dabbled in it, but that's been almost a scandal.
Wolf, I want to thank you very much for your time and for this interview.
You're welcome.
